greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n such that there is exactly one part which occurs twice, while all other parts occur only once.
comment: Also number of partitions of n such that if k is the largest part, then, with exactly one exception, all the integers 1,2,...,k occur as parts. Example: a(7)=4 because we have [4,2,1], [3,3,1], [3,2,2] and [3,1,1,1,1]. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Apr 18 2006
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
example: a(7) = 4 because we have 4 such partitions of 7: [1,1,2,3], [1,1,5], [2,2,3], [1,3,3].
The a(2) = 1 through a(11) = 13 partitions described in the name are the following (empty columns not shown). The Heinz numbers of these partitions are given by A060687.
The a(2) = 1 through a(10) = 8 partitions described in Emeric Deutsch's comment are the following (empty columns not shown). The Heinz numbers of these partitions are given by A325284.
maple: b:= proc(n, i, t) option remember; `if`(n>i*(i+3-2*t)/2, 0,
mathematica: b[n_, i_, t_] := b[n, i, t] = If[n > i*(i + 3 - 2*t)/2, 0, If[n == 0, t, b[n, i - 1, t] + If[i > n, 0,  b[n - i, i - 1, t] + If[t == 1 || 2*i > n, 0, b[n - 2*i, i - 1, 1]]]]]; a[n_] := b[n, n, 0]; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 100} ] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 20 2016, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Vladeta Jovovic_, Feb 12 2004
